awd_abstract_narration:
The 2017 Seminar on Stochastic Processes (SSP) will be held at University of Virginia in Charlottesville, VA on March 8-11, 2017. These seminars have been held annually since 1981; they have become the most important regular conference series for probabilists in North America. They bring together a diverse group of accomplished and early career researchers in probability and stochastic processes.  The primary goal is to provide a platform for the dissemination of the most recent significant progress in research in the theory of stochastic processes, and to enable participants to discuss their work in an informal atmosphere.

Stochastic processes are basic building blocks of the way that randomness exhibits itself in the real world, and are used to model a wide range of physical, biological, ecological, and financial phenomena. The Seminar on Stochastic Processes is a fixture in probability, and many prominent probabilists attend every year. The format of this meeting is based on the success of recent Seminars on Stochastic Processes. There will be five one hour talks and a tutorial session consisting of two 90 minute lectures, all delivered by distinguished speakers on key recent themes and developments in stochastic process research and their important connections to other parts of mathematics and the sciences. This conference will also feature opportunities for early career researchers to present their own research and for the discussion of open problems.

More details are available at the conference website

http://faculty.virginia.edu/ssp17/
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The NSF funding (DMS-1663552) supported the 2017 Seminar on Stochastic Processes which was held at University of Virginia (UVA) in Charlottesville from Wednesday March 8 to Saturday March 11, 2017. The local organizers of the event were Christian Gromoll, Tai Melcher, and Leonid Petrov, all from the Department of Mathematics at UVA.

The Seminar on Stochastic Processes has been held annually since 1981.  It has become one of the most important regular conference series for probabilists in North America. This series brings together a diverse group of accomplished researchers and young investigators in probability and stochastic processes.  The primary goal is to provide a platform for the dissemination of the most recent significant progress in research, and to enable participants to discuss their work with others. The 2017 installment of the Seminar was no exception in this series.

The program of the conference consisted of five one-hour talks by invited speakers (given on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday), and two tutorial lectures(given on Wednesday). In addition to these plenary talks, there were 16 contributed short talks, 14 poster presentations, an open problem session, and a panel discussion on career development topics relevant to early career researchers in probability. The plenary speakers and panel discussants are listed in Appendix 1. The titles of the plenary talk are given in Appendix 2.

 

Intellectual Merit

The Seminar in Stochastic Processes has had a tremendous impact on the probability community. It is a fixture in probability, and many of the most prominent probabilists in North America have given talks in this conference series and make a habit of attending it every year. 

 

This year's plenary talks focused on a variety of topics in theoretical and applied probability, including mixing properties of product spaces,length and weight asymptotics for minimum mean-weight cycles,universality for singular stochastic partial differential equations,limit theorems for divergence integrals via Malliavin calculus, limit theorems for branching Brownian motions,and representations of functionals of Poisson random measures.These topics are all relevant to current important topics in probability research and were presented by some of the foremost experts in these areas.

 

Broader Impacts 

The 2017 Seminar on Stochastic Processesattracted 95 participants from the US and other countries (Canada, Germany, Israel,  Singapore, and  Turkey), which included 26 graduate students, 35 early career researchers (up to 5 years after PhD), 16 women, and 9 members of other underrepresented groups.

The NSF support was given to plenary speakers and offered to selected early career participants (graduate students and postdocs), women and members of other underrepresented groups, and faculty who may not have otherwise been able to attend the event. Namely, the support for lodging in Charlottesville and travel expenses up to $700 was given to 52 participants. 

 

Appendix 1.  Speakers and selection committees

Invited speakers:

  • David Nualart, University of Kansas (Kai Lai Chung Lecturer)
  • Paul Dupuis, Brown University
  • Massimiliano Gubinelli, Universit?t Bonn, Germany
  • Jason Schweinsberg, University of California, San Diego
  • Nike Sun, University of California, Berkeley

The invited speakers were chosen by a Scientific Committee comprising

  • Amarjit Budhiraja, University of North Carolina
  • Krzysztof Burdzy, University of Washington
  • Ren? Carmona, Princeton University
  • Sandra Cerrai, University of Maryland
  • Steve Evans, University of California, Berkeley
  • H. Christian Gromoll, University of Virginia
  • Davar Khoshnevisan, University of Utah
  • Tai Melcher, University of Virginia
  • Leonid Petrov, University of Virginia
  • Kavita Ramanan, Brown University
  • Thomas Salisbury, York University, Toronto
  • Frederi Viens, Purdue University
  • Ruth Williams, University of California, San Diego

The tutorial speaker Elchanan Mossel (MIT) was chosen by the committee comprising

  • Jian Ding, University of Chicago
  • Vadim Gorin, MIT
  • Leonid Petrov, University of Virginia
  • Ruth Williams, University of California, San Diego
  • Tianyi Zheng, Stanford University

The panel at the discussion consisted of

  • Peter Baxendale, University of Southern California 
  • Guodong Pang, Penn State University
  • Amber Puha, Cal State San Marcos
  • Douglas Rizzolo, University of Delaware
  • Frederi Viens, Michigan State University

The participants of the panel discussion were chosen by the local organizers.

 

Appendix 2. Titles and abstracts of talks and posters

Elchanan Mossel (MIT) - Mixing in product spaces

Nike Sun (Berkeley) - Supercritical minimum mean-weight cycles

Massimiliano Gubinelli (Bonn) - Weak universality of fluctuations and singular stochastic PDEs

David Nualart (University of Kansas) - Malliavin calculus and central limit theorems 

Jason Schweinsberg (UC San Diego) - Yaglom-type limit theorems for branching Brownian motion with absorption 

Paul Dupuis (Brown) - A variational representation for functionals of a Poisson random measure and applications 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2018
Modified by: Tai A Melcher
